fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given two chain complexes C_\bullet and D_\bullet with two chain maps f, g : C \to D between them, a chain homotopy from f to g is given by a family of maps h_n : C_n \to D_{n+1}, such that d_{n+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_n + h_{n-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_n = f_n - g_n. Note that the two dâ€™s denote the boundary map of different chain complexes.
The chain homotopy can be written as h : f \to g or as h : C \to D. This causes no confusion, and the latter is convenient in situations where the maps f, g matter less than their difference f - g.

fr:title.text: quasi-isomorphism between projective complexes is homotopy equivalence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: quasi-isomorphism between projective complexes is homotopy equivalence

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given two chain complexes C_\bullet , D_\bullet and a quasi-isomorphism f : C_\bullet \to D_\bullet , if all the objects involved are projective, then f has a homotopy inverse.

Consider the mapping cone \operatorname {Cone}(f), whose objects are given by \operatorname {Cone}_n (f) = C_{n-1} \oplus D_n. Since direct sums of projective objects are still projective, \operatorname {Cone}(f) is also a chain complex of projective objects. We have a short exact sequence of chain complexes 0 \to D_\bullet \to \operatorname {Cone}_\bullet (f) \to C_{\bullet - 1} \to 0, which induces a long exact sequence of homologies, in which the boundary maps H_n (C) \to H_n (D) are given by f.

However, we know f is a quasi-isomorphism. Therefore the boundary maps are all isomorphisms. So by exactness of the sequence, H_n (\operatorname {Cone}(f)) must all be zero. But this means \operatorname {Cone}(f) is an acyclic complex, and therefore a projective resolution of 0. Since projective resolutions are unique up to chain homotopy, we have a chain homotopy from \operatorname {Cone}(f) to 0. Throwing away the trivial components, we get a degree 1 map h_n : \operatorname {Cone}_n (f) \to \operatorname {Cone}_{n+1} (f) such that d_{n+1} h_n + h_{n-1} d_n = 1. Writing it down in components, we have \begin {aligned} h_n^{CC} &: C_{n-1} \to C_n \\ h_n^{CD} &: C_{n-1} \to D_{n+1} \\ h_n^{DC} &: D_n \to C_n \\ h_n^{DD} &: D_n \to D_{n+1} \\ \end {aligned} such that \begin {aligned} h_n^{CC} d^C_n + d^C_{n+1} h_{n+1}^{CC} + 1 &= h^{DC}_n f_{n} \\ d^C_n h^{DC}_n &= h^{DC}_n d^D_{n+1} \\ f_n h^{CC}_n + d^D_{n+1} h^{CD}_n + h_n^{DD} f_n &= h^{CD}_n d^C_n \\ f_n h^{DC}_n + d^D_{n+1} h^{DD}_n + h^{DD}_n d^D_{n+1} &= 1. \end {aligned} The second equation shows that h^{DC}_\bullet forms a chain map. The first and fourth equation then shows that h^{DC} f and f h^{DC} are homotopic to the identity, respectively, with homotopies given by h^{CC} and h^{DD}. Therefore f has a homotopy inverse.
Curiously, there is an extra equation here, showing that h^{CD} is not a chain map and giving the exact deviation.

html:ul.html:li: A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0 and h \mathbin {\circ } d_C \mathbin {\circ } h = h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } r_k + r_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k = \textrm {id}, where d is the boundary operator on E_\bullet . In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_\bullet , rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

On the other hand, given only the homotopy operator, we expect to have d \mathbin {\circ } h + h \mathbin {\circ } d = \textrm {id} - g \mathbin {\circ } f. And since g \mathbin {\circ } f should be the projector of C onto the subspace D, \textrm {id} - g \mathbin {\circ } f should be the projector onto E. We are thus led to proving p = d \mathbin {\circ } h + h \mathbin {\circ } d is indeed a projector. \begin {aligned} p_k \mathbin {\circ } p_k &= (d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k) \mathbin {\circ } (d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } \overbrace {h_k \mathbin {\circ } d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } \overbrace {h_k \mathbin {\circ } h_{k-1}}^{0} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \\ &\qquad + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } \underbrace {d_k \mathbin {\circ } d_{k+1}}_{0} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \mathbin {\circ } h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k = p_k. \end {aligned} Therefore we conclude that p_k splits C_k \cong D_k \oplus E_k. More over, p \mathbin {\circ } d = d \mathbin {\circ } h \mathbin {\circ } d = d \mathbin {\circ } p, meaning p is a chain map, and therefore the splitting is compatible with the boundary operator. Since h \mathbin {\circ } p = p \mathbin {\circ } h = h \mathbin {\circ } d \mathbin {\circ } h = h, the homotopy is also compatible with the splitting, so we can restrict it onto E_k to get a homotopy from \textrm {id}_E to 0.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h(\textrm {id} - p) = h - h \mathbin {\circ } d \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, such that \pi \mathbin {\circ } \iota = \textrm {id}, and \pi \mathbin {\circ } h = h \mathbin {\circ } \iota = h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.
We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted \pi _{\rho } : C \to D, \iota _{\rho } : D \to C and h_{\rho } : C \to C, respectively.
Given two chain complexes C_\bullet , D_\bullet , the natural notion of morphisms between them is chain maps, i.e. a sequence of maps f_n : C_n \to D_n such that all the squares commute.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} \cdots & {C_{n+1}} & {C_n} & {C_{n-1}} & \cdots \\ \cdots & {D_{n+1}} & {D_n} & {D_{n-1}} & \cdots \arrow ["d", from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow ["{f_n}"', from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["{f_{n-1}}"', from=1-4, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-3, to=2-4] \arrow ["d"', from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow ["d", from=1-2, to=1-3] \arrow [from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow [from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-4, to=1-5] \arrow [from=2-4, to=2-5] \arrow ["{f_{n+1}}"', from=1-2, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}
